> In my codebase, I have a simple client and server that should work 
if 
> the server receives a hello message from the client and then echos 
back 
> to the client. How do I code this in Junit? It seems the with the 
> TestSuite multiple tests could run concurrently-- is there some way 
to 
> start up the server maybe sleep for a couple seconds and then run 
the 
> client test and shutdown the server?

JUnit is designed to be used as a unit testing framework.  In this 
case, for example, it would be easier for you to use one of the 
patterns below to test your client/server program, than to try to do 
integration/acceptance/user testing.

Patterns you can use to test your application:
SELF SHUNT TEST: http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki?SelfShuntPattern
MOCK-OBJECT: http://www.c2.com/cgi/wiki?MockObject

(Also: search the archives for previous posts on the topic.)

The basic premise is:  you want to test components one at a time.  If 
you try to test both the client *AND* the server at the same time, it 
would make it harder for you to find where the actual problem lies.  
So:  test the components (units) one at a time.  If the component 
interacts with other components, fake them out.  This way, you have a 
much higher guarantee that the problem will be in the component under 
test.
